member.name: T:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectData.Signature
member.remarks: Describes an input or output signature, composed of descriptions.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectData.Signature.Semantics
member.summary: Gets or sets the semantics

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectData.Signature.Bytecode
member.summary: Gets the bytecode of this signature. This field is only valid for Input Vertex Shader.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectData.Signature.Hashcode
member.summary: Gets the hashcode associated with the signature bytecode.

remarks.p: A shader can take n inputs and can produce m outputs. The order of the input (or output) parameters, their associated types, and any attached semantics make up the shader signature. Each shader has an input and an output signature.

When compiling a shader or an effect, some API calls validate shader signatures That is, they compare the output signature of one shader (like a vertex shader) with the input signature of another shader (like a pixel shader). This ensures that a shader outputs data that is compatible with a downstream shader that is consuming that data. Compatible means that a shader signature is a exact-match subset of the preceding shader stage. Exact match means parameter types and semantics must exactly match. Subset means that a parameter that is not required by a downstream stage, does not need to include that parameter in its shader signature.
Get a shader-signature from a shader or an effect by calling APIs such as .

member.name: M:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectData.Semantic.#ctor
member.summary: Semantic

member.name: M:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectData.Semantic.#ctor(System.String,System.Byte,System.Byte,System.Byte,System.Byte,System.Byte,System.Byte,System.Byte)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of class.
member.param: A predefined string that determines the functionality of certain pipeline stages.
The per-component-data type that is stored in a register.
Mask which indicates which components of a register are used.
sk which indicates whether a given component is never written (if the signature is an output signature) or always read (if the signature is an input signature).
Indicates which stream the geometry shader is using for the signature parameter.

dd.p: A per-parameter string that identifies how the data will be used.
Semantic index that modifies the semantic. Used to differentiate different parameters that use the same semantic.
The register that will contain this variable's data.
A predefined string that determines the functionality of certain pipeline stages. See D3D10_NAME.
The per-component-data type that is stored in a register. See D3D10_REGISTER_COMPONENT_TYPE. Each register can store up to four-components of data.
Mask which indicates which components of a register are used.
Mask which indicates whether a given component is never written (if the signature is an output signature) or always read (if the signature is an input signature).
Indicates which stream the geometry shader is using for the signature parameter.

member.name: T:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectCompilerFlags
member.summary: Effect Compiler flags.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectCompilerFlags.Debug
member.summary: Directs the compiler to insert debug file/line/type/symbol information into the output code.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectCompilerFlags.SkipValidation
member.summary: Directs the compiler not to validate the generated code against known capabilities and constraints. We recommend that you use this constant only with shaders that have been successfully compiled in the past. DirectX always validates shaders before it sets them to a device.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectCompilerFlags.SkipOptimization
member.summary: Directs the compiler to skip optimization steps during code generation. We recommend that you set this constant for debug purposes only.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectCompilerFlags.PackMatrixRowMajor
member.summary: Directs the compiler to pack matrices in row-major order on input and output from the shader.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectCompilerFlags.PackMatrixColumnMajor
member.summary: Directs the compiler to pack matrices in column-major order on input and output from the shader. This type of packing is generally more efficient because a series of dot-products can then perform vector-matrix multiplication.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectCompilerFlags.PartialPrecision
member.summary: Directs the compiler to perform all computations with partial precision. If you set this constant, the compiled code might run faster on some hardware.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectCompilerFlags.AvoidFlowControl
member.summary: Directs the compiler to not use flow-control constructs where possible.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectCompilerFlags.PreferFlowControl
member.summary: Directs the compiler to use flow-control constructs where possible.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectCompilerFlags.EnableStrictness
member.summary: Forces strict compile, which might not allow for legacy syntax.
member.remarks: By default, the compiler disables strictness on deprecated syntax.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectCompilerFlags.EnableBackwardsCompatibility
member.summary: Directs the compiler to enable older shaders to compile to 5_0 targets.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectCompilerFlags.IeeeStrictness
member.summary: Forces the IEEE strict compile.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectCompilerFlags.OptimizationLevel0
member.summary: Directs the compiler to use the lowest optimization level. If you set this constant, the compiler might produce slower code but produces the code more quickly. Set this constant when you develop the shader iteratively.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectCompilerFlags.OptimizationLevel1
member.summary: Directs the compiler to use the second lowest optimization level.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectCompilerFlags.OptimizationLevel2
member.summary: Directs the compiler to use the second highest optimization level.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectCompilerFlags.OptimizationLevel3
member.summary: Directs the compiler to use the highest optimization level. If you set this constant, the compiler produces the best possible code but might take significantly longer to do so. Set this constant for final builds of an application when performance is the most important factor.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectCompilerFlags.WarningsAreErrors
member.summary: Directs the compiler to treat all warnings as errors when it compiles the shader code. We recommend that you use this constant for new shader code, so that you can resolve all warnings and lower the number of hard-to-find code defects.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectCompilerFlags.None
member.summary: None.

member.param: The name of the bitmap data to load.
member.returns: A bitmap data object.

member.name: T:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.VertexBufferLayout
member.summary: A description of a vertex elements for particular slot for the input-assembler stage. This structure is related to .
member.remarks: Because requires to have the same , , this structure encapsulates a set of for a particular slot, instance count.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.VertexBufferLayout.SlotIndex
member.summary: Vertex buffer slot index.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.VertexBufferLayout.InstanceCount
member.summary: The number of instances to draw using the same per-instance data before advancing in the buffer by one element. This value must be 0 for an element that contains per-vertex data (the slot class is set to ).

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.VertexBufferLayout.VertexElements

member.name: T:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.VertexElement
member.summary: A description of a single element for the input-assembler stage. This structure is related to .
member.remarks: Because requires to have the same , and , the structure encapsulates a set of for a particular slot, classification and instance data step rate. Unlike the default , this structure accepts a semantic name with a postfix number that will be automatically extracted to the semantic index.

member.name: F:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.VertexElement.AppendAligned
member.summary: Returns a value that can be used for the offset parameter of an InputElement to indicate that the element should be aligned directly after the previous element, including any packing if neccessary.
member.returns: A value used to align input elements.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.VertexElement.ConvertTypeToFormat(System.Type)
member.summary: Converts a type to a .
member.returns: The equivalent Format.
member.exception: If the convertion for this type is not supported.

dd.p: The HLSL semantic associated with this element in a shader input-signature.

The semantic index for the element. A semantic index modifies a semantic, with an integer index number. A semantic index is only needed in a case where there is more than one element with the same semantic. For example, a 4x4 matrix would have four components each with the semantic name
, however each of the four component would have different semantic indices (0, 1, 2, and 3).
The data type of the element data. See .
Optional. Offset (in bytes) between each element. Use D3D11_APPEND_ALIGNED_ELEMENT for convenience to define the current element directly after the previous one, including any packing if necessary.

member.name: T:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.VertexElementAttribute
member.summary: An attribute to use on a field in a structure, to describe a single vertex element for the input-assembler stage.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.VertexElementAttribute.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the struct.
member.remarks: If the semantic name contains a postfix number, this number will be used as a semantic index. The will be mapped from the field type.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.VertexElementAttribute.#ctor(System.String,SharpDX.DXGI.Format)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the struct.
member.remarks: If the semantic name contains a postfix number, this number will be used as a semantic index.

member.name: M:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.VertexElementAttribute.#ctor(System.String,System.Int32,SharpDX.DXGI.Format,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the struct.

dd.p: The HLSL semantic associated with this element in a shader input-signature.

The semantic index for the element. A semantic index modifies a semantic, with an integer index number. A semantic index is only needed in a case where there is more than one element with the same semantic. For example, a 4x4 matrix would have four components each with the semantic name
, however each of the four component would have different semantic indices (0, 1, 2, and 3).
The data type of the element data. See .
Optional. Offset (in bytes) between each element. Use D3D11_APPEND_ALIGNED_ELEMENT for convenience to define the current element directly after the previous one, including any packing if necessary.

member.name: T:SharpDX.Toolkit.Graphics.EffectParameterClass
member.summary: Values that identify the class of a shader variable.
member.remarks: The class of a shader variable is not a programming class; the class identifies the variable class such as scalar, vector, object, and so on.

dd.p: The shader variable is a scalar.
The shader variable is a vector.
The shader variable is a row-major matrix.
The shader variable is a column-major matrix.
The shader variable is an object.
The shader variable is a structure.
The shader variable is a class.
The shader variable is an interface.

summary.p: Values that identify various data, texture, and buffer types that can be assigned to a shader variable.

remarks.p: A call to the method returns a value in the Type member of a structure.

The types in a structured buffer describe the structure of the elements in the buffer. The layout of these types generally match their C++ struct counterparts. The following examples show structured buffers:

pre.code: struct mystruct {float4 val; uint ind;}; RWStructuredBuffer<mystruct> rwbuf; RWStructuredBuffer<float3> rwbuf2;

dd.p: The variable is a void reference.
The variable is a boolean.
The variable is an integer.
The variable is a floating-point number.
The variable is a string.
The variable is a texture.
The variable is a 1D texture.
The variable is a 2D texture.
The variable is a 3D texture.
The variable is a texture cube.
The variable is a sampler.
The variable is a sampler.
The variable is a sampler.
The variable is a sampler.
The variable is a sampler.
The variable is a pixel shader.
The variable is a vertex shader.
The variable is a pixel shader.
The variable is a vertex shader.
The variable is an unsigned integer.
The variable is an 8-bit unsigned integer.
The variable is a geometry shader.
The variable is a rasterizer-state object.
The variable is a depth-stencil-state object.
The variable is a blend-state object.
The variable is a buffer.
The variable is a constant buffer.
The variable is a texture buffer.
The variable is a 1D-texture array.
The variable is a 2D-texture array.
The variable is a render-target view.
The variable is a depth-stencil view.
The variable is a 2D-multisampled texture.
The variable is a 2D-multisampled-texture array.
The variable is a texture-cube array.
The variable holds a compiled hull-shader binary.
The variable holds a compiled domain-shader binary.
The variable is an interface.
The variable holds a compiled compute-shader binary.
The variable is a double precision (64-bit) floating-point number.
The variable is a 1D read-and-write texture.
The variable is an array of 1D read-and-write textures.
The variable is a 2D read-and-write texture.
The variable is an array of 2D read-and-write textures.
The variable is a 3D read-and-write texture.
The variable is a read-and-write buffer.
The variable is a byte-address buffer.
The variable is a read-and-write byte-address buffer.
The variable is a structured buffer.
For more information about structured buffer, see the Remarks section.
The variable is a read-and-write structured buffer.
The variable is an append structured buffer.
The variable is a consume structured buffer.
